Award.AwardTitle: Just-in-Time Adaptive Interventions for Emotion Regulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: In the last 25 years, there has been an eruption of research on the prevalence and impact of work-related emotions. Research has shown that negative emotional reactions can impair employees’ task performance and result in counterproductive work behavior and, in severe cases, insider threat behavior. Much of this research has been guided by theories predicting causal event-emotion-behavior sequences. However, the many empirical studies in this area are either correlational rather than causal (e.g., ecological momentary assessment studies) or conducted in the laboratory rather than in situ. This research will help employees gain strategies to regulate their emotions, thereby potentially improving task performance and deterring counterproductive and insider threat behavior. Thus, the research has the potential to improve employee well-being. The research also has the potential to aid organizations in weakening the links between stressful events and insider threat behavior on the part of their employees. Finally, this research will illustrate the JITAI as a new and very different type of intervention that can fruitfully augment traditional interventions in a variety of topic areas within the organizational sciences (e.g., occupational safety interventions, sexual harassment prevention interventions, leader development interventions, and technical skills training interventions).<br/><br/><br/>The current pair of studies will manipulate emotional experience via randomly assigned Just-in-Time Adaptive Interventions (JITAIs), also known as ecological momentary interventions. Tailored interventions are needed to help individuals regulate negative emotions in the moment—when most needed and before the resulting deleterious performance outcomes manifest. As such, the JITAIs in the current research are focused on emotion regulation, thereby providing causal tests of the role of emotion on behavior as well as testing additional research questions involving situational and dispositional moderators of emotion-behavior relationships. Unlike standard interventions, these JITAIs are within-person interventions that capitalize on temporal states of vulnerability (e.g., high levels of negative emotion) and aspects of the current context (e.g., the nature of the emotion-causing episode, the feasibility of completing the intervention at that particular moment) to optimize treatment effectiveness. Specifically, in the proposed studies, participants will repeatedly be randomly (re-)assigned to different cognitively-focused emotion reappraisal interventions or to no intervention (control condition) over the course of several work weeks. The reappraisal strategies to be contrasted against each other (and against a control condition) include imagining that a negative emotional stimulus or situation had a positive outcome, altering the impact of the emotional stimulus by adopting a more-or-less objective perspective, and interpreting the focal emotion in a manner that facilitates an accepting, observing, non-judgmental relationship to emotions. The first study is a micro-randomized trial that will provide for causal inferences regarding emotion and the effects of three cognitive reappraisal JITAIs in achieving proximal (i.e., decision-point and day level) emotion and performance outcomes. The results from the first study will permit the optimization of decision rules (e.g., dropping a less effective intervention, including decision rules for which intervention should be used when based on context) to inform the second study. The second study is a randomized control trial that will evaluate the effectiveness of the JITAIs in achieving distal (i.e., end-of-study and post-study) outcomes against control conditions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Emotions are transient and impactful, bearing consequences not only for employee well-being but also for how well employees perform their jobs. As such, emotions need to be carefully regulated at work, and successful regulation depends on the selected emotion regulation strategy, the situation, and the person in question. The current research married ecological field research with an experimental (i.e., causal) design to develop and test a "just-in-time adaptive intervention" (JITAI)?an intervention technique that provides personalized and timely interventions based on real-time data to support individuals in achieving behavior change and improving their well-being. 

Intellectual Merit

One key advantage of JITAIs is that they utilize the benefits of both field and experimental research designs and thus enable researchers to draw causal inferences from a field study (i.e., employees at work). Our JITAI was designed to provide brief cognitive reappraisal activities to employees during their workdays, prompting them to think differently about recent emotional experiences so as to reduce negative emotions and increase positive emotions in the moment.

The first study was designed as an initial test of the JITAI using a micro-randomized trial design and within-person randomization to evaluate the effectiveness of three reappraisal activities on momentary emotions. We found that this initial version of the JITAI was effective in increasing positive emotions but not in reducing negative emotions, and that some reappraisal activities were more effective than others. We then used these findings to optimize the JITAI: we separated and emphasized both recall and reappraisal of that situation or emotion, dropped the most ineffective reappraisal activity, and modified the wording of the remaining two reappraisal activities to better target negative emotions.

Having optimized the JITAI, we then designed the second study as a randomized controlled trial using between-person randomization to test whether the JITAI could influence distal outcomes: improving daily emotions and daily job performance as well as job performance in the month post-study. We found that the optimized JITAI improved daily positive and negative emotions, improved daily job performance and reduced daily counterproductive work behavior during the study, and improved performance and reduced counterproductive behavior in the month following the study.

Our work illustrates the JITAI as a new and very different type of intervention that can fruitfully augment traditional interventions in a variety of topic-areas within the organizational sciences. Specifically, researchers can adopt this two-step developmental process (viz., a microrandomized trial to facilitate optimization followed by a randomized control trial to assess effectiveness) for the creation of employee-centered interventions for topics such as employee safety, team coordination and performance, and sexual harassment. Researchers can also optimize the intervention to provide higher or lower levels of support at certain times, in certain situations, and for certain people.

Broader Impacts

The results of this research causally demonstrate that brief and virtually costless intervention activities can support employee emotion regulation at work. A JITAI based on cognitive reappraisal that can increase emotional valence holds promise as a practical employee wellness tool. As work life commonly includes uncontrolled events that can erode motivation and increase stress, organizations and employees need options for mitigating the impact of uncertain and complex stimuli at work. By adopting and implementing JITAIs, organizations can alleviate these deleterious factors for employees, in the same manner that organizations aiming to improve work life and increase retention can offer exercise classes, team building activities, or mindfulness training to provide respite, recovery, social support, and strain reduction. Importantly, though, employees need not wait for organizational cooperation: they can self-initiate JITAIs for themselves during occasions and locations of most need.

In sum, this research is aimed at increasing the well-being of employees and more generally individuals in society. We have developed a one-page infographic summarizing our findings for the general public, thereby facilitating greater engagement with and application of science on the part of the general public. The infographic can be found here: https://tinyurl.com/JITAIinfographic
